thread.title: White House lifts 40-year-old ban on tour photos (VIDEO)
thread.title_full: White House lifts 40-year-old ban on tour photos (VIDEO)

title: White House lifts 40-year-old ban on tour photos (VIDEO)
text:
White House lifts 40-year-old ban on tour photos (VIDEO) Thursday July 2, 2015 Print Article 
Michelle Obama posted a video to her various social media accounts in which she tears one of the White House’s ‘no photos or social media allowed’ signs in half. — Picture courtesy of Twitter WASHINGTON, July 2 — The White House yesterday lifted a 40-year ban on visitors taking photos, and much-prized selfies, on tours of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. 
Tourists to “the People’s House” yesterday were greeted with a changed sign saying, “Photography is Encouraged.” 
The First Lady Michelle Obama announced the decision to the broader public on her Instagram account, ceremoniously ripping up the previous “No Photos” sign. Big news! Excited to announce we're lifting the ban on cameras and photos on public tours at the @WhiteHouse ! https://t.co/b0v17puClm — The First Lady (@FLOTUS) July 1, 2015 
But there are a few catches: Flashes and video recording or streaming is still prohibited. 
In the State Dining Room, 47-year-old visitor Korey Richardson, was excited by the new rules. 
“This is my first time here,” he said. “I’m taking tons of pictures, at least 30 so far. I’ve already uploaded some to Facebook friends.” — AFP More Stories for You:
